cluster.title: Hillary Clinton testifies before US House panel on Jeffrey Epstein investigation.

synthesis.narrative:
## State of the Story: Hillary Clinton Testifies in House Epstein Investigation

### Key Facts Established

Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton testified before the House Oversight Committee on Thursday, February 26, 2026, as part of a congressional investigation into Jeffrey Epstein [1][2][3][4][5]. The closed-door deposition took place at the Chappaqua Performing Arts Center in New York, near the Clintons' home [1][2].

Clinton maintained she has "no knowledge" that would assist the investigation and stated she "had no idea about their criminal activities" and does not "recall ever encountering Mr. Epstein" [1][5]. She also said she "never flew on his plane or visited his island home or offices" [5]. Clinton had previously given a sworn declaration to the committee on January 13 stating she had no knowledge of crimes committed by Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell [1].

The testimony was compelled by subpoena from Republican committee chair James Comer after the Clintons' offers of sworn statements were rejected [4]. Both Clintons were threatened with contempt of Congress charges if they refused to appear [3][4]. Former President Bill Clinton is scheduled to testify Friday, marking "the first time that a former president has been forced to testify before Congress" [4].

### Procedural Disruption

The proceedings were temporarily interrupted when conservative influencer Benny Johnson posted photos of Clinton testifying on social media, which he attributed to Rep. Lauren Boebert (R-Colo.) [1][2][5]. Clinton's lawyers "loudly protested" the breach, arguing it violated rules against taking pictures during closed-door hearings [1][2]. The testimony went "off the record" while officials addressed the incident [1]. Boebert briefly left the meeting but returned after a short time [1].

### Political Accusations

Clinton delivered a scathing opening statement accusing Republicans of conducting a "fishing expedition" designed to "distract attention from President Trump's actions and to cover them up" [1][2][3]. She characterized the proceedings as "partisan political theatre" and "an insult to the American people" [2]. Clinton argued the committee should instead question Trump "under oath about the tens of thousands of times he shows up in the Epstein files" [2][5].

Committee Chair Comer defended the investigation, stating "this isn't a partisan witch hunt" and noting it was "a bipartisan motion, supported by the Democrats, to bring the Clintons in" [5].

### Timeline of Events

- **January 13, 2026**: Clinton provided sworn declaration to committee stating no knowledge of Epstein crimes [1]
- **February 26, 2026**: Hillary Clinton's closed-door deposition at Chappaqua Performing Arts Center [1][2][3][4][5]
- **February 27, 2026**: Bill Clinton scheduled to testify [2][3][4]

### Source Agreement and Disagreement

All sources agree on the basic facts: Clinton testified Thursday, denied knowledge of Epstein's crimes, and accused Republicans of partisan motives. Sources consistently report the photo incident involving Boebert and the temporary suspension of proceedings.

Sources differ in emphasis: Conservative outlet Breitbart [4] focuses on the historical significance and procedural aspects, while liberal-leaning sources [2][3] emphasize Clinton's criticisms of Republicans. All sources note that neither Clinton has been accused of wrongdoing [4][5].

citations.title: Hillary Clinton says she has no knowledge to help Jeffrey Epstein investigation
citations.quote: Former Secretary of State Hillary Clinton said she has 'no knowledge' that would assist the House Oversight Committee in its investigation involving late sex offender Jeffrey Epstein in her opening statement before the panel Thursday.

citations.title: Hillary Clinton accuses Republicans of 'fishing expedition' in Epstein testimony
citations.quote: Hillary Clinton delivered a withering rebuke to a congressional committee investigating her supposed links to Jeffrey Epstein on Thursday, accusing its Republican members of embarking on a 'fishing expedition' intended to cover up and deflect attention from the actions of Donald Trump.

citations.title: Hillary Clinton calls for Trump to testify at US House Epstein hearing
citations.quote: Former United States Secretary of State Hillary Clinton has condemned the conduct of a Republican-led panel investigating links to convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein, accusing congressional lawmakers of trying to 'protect one political party and one public official'.

citations.title: Hillary Clinton to Appear as Part of U.S. House Panel's Jeffrey Epstein Probe
citations.quote: It will be the first time that a former president has been forced to testify before Congress.

citations.title: Hillary Clinton says she has no new information on Epstein in House Oversight testimony
citations.quote: I had no idea about their criminal activities. I do not recall ever encountering Mr. Epstein. I never flew on his plane or visited his island home or offices

Clinton denied having any knowledge that would assist the investigation and said she never met Epstein
Proceedings temporarily suspended after Rep. Lauren Boebert allegedly shared photos on social media
Clinton accused Republicans of conducting 'fishing expedition' to protect Trump
Bill Clinton scheduled to testify Friday, marking first time former president forced to testify before Congress
Committee chair defended investigation as bipartisan effort

Hillary Clinton said she has no knowledge that would assist the investigation

The testimony took place at the Chappaqua Performing Arts Center in New York
Bill Clinton is scheduled to testify on Friday
This will be the first time a former president has been forced to testify before Congress

The testimony was interrupted after Benny Johnson posted a photo from the proceedings on social media
Rep. Lauren Boebert provided the photo to Benny Johnson
Hillary Clinton accused Republicans of conducting a partisan fishing expedition to protect Trump
Hillary Clinton said Trump appears tens of thousands of times in the Epstein files
The Clintons were threatened with contempt of Congress charges
Neither Clinton has been accused of wrongdoing related to Epstein
Committee Chair James Comer said this was a bipartisan motion supported by Democrats
Hillary Clinton did not invoke her Fifth Amendment right during questioning
Hillary Clinton had previously interacted with Ghislaine Maxwell at Clinton Foundation conferences

frames.name: Partisan Political Theater
frames.description: Frames the hearing as a Republican-led distraction from Trump's connections to Epstein, emphasizing Clinton's accusations of partisan motives
frames.emphasis: Clinton's criticism of Republicans for targeting her while avoiding scrutiny of Trump's documented connections to Epstein

frames.name: Congressional Oversight Process
frames.description: Presents the hearing as a legitimate bipartisan congressional investigation into Epstein connections
frames.emphasis: The procedural aspects, historical significance, and committee chair's assertion of bipartisan support

frames.name: Historical Precedent
frames.description: Emphasizes the unprecedented nature of forcing a former president to testify before Congress
frames.emphasis: The rarity and significance of compelling presidential testimony, comparing to Gerald Ford in 1983

frames.name: Procedural Disruption
frames.description: Focuses on the breach of protocol when photos were leaked from the closed-door hearing
frames.emphasis: The violation of rules by Rep. Boebert and the temporary suspension of proceedings

outlierPerspectives: Breitbart uniquely emphasizes this as the first time a former president has been 'forced' to testify, framing it as compulsion rather than cooperation
Al Jazeera alone contextualizes this within broader criticism of the Trump administration's 'initial resistance to publishing the government's full Epstein file'
missingContext: Specific details about what Trump's documented connections to Epstein actually entail beyond general references to 'Epstein files'
The scope and timeline of the broader House Oversight Committee investigation into Epstein
Details about what other witnesses have been called or what evidence the committee has gathered
Explanation of why the Clintons were specifically subpoenaed if they claim no relevant knowledge
Context about the 2008 plea deal mentioned and its current relevance to the investigation

predictions.text: Bill Clinton's testimony on Friday will face intense scrutiny and likely generate significant media coverage
predictions.basis: Historical significance as first forced presidential testimony since Ford in 1983

predictions.text: Republicans will face criticism for procedural violations and potential ethics investigation regarding photo leak
predictions.basis: Clinton lawyers' protests and violation of closed-door hearing rules

predictions.text: Investigation will expand to examine Trump's connections to Epstein more thoroughly
predictions.basis: Clinton's accusations about Trump appearing 'tens of thousands of times' in Epstein files

predictions.text: Committee will issue final report with limited new revelations about Clinton involvement
predictions.basis: Clinton's consistent denials and lack of accusations against either Clinton

deepAnalysis.historicalContext: This testimony represents a rare instance of compelling high-profile political figures to testify under subpoena about criminal associations. The last time a former president was forced to testify before Congress was Gerald Ford in 1983. The Epstein case has created ongoing political reverberations since his 2019 death, with various political figures facing scrutiny over their connections. The investigation occurs against the backdrop of intense partisan divisions and the 2024 election cycle, where Trump remains a central figure. Clinton's strategy of deflecting to Trump's alleged Epstein connections mirrors broader Democratic tactics of turning Republican investigations back on Trump.
implications: Sets precedent for congressional power to compel testimony from former presidents and high-ranking officials
Demonstrates ongoing political weaponization of congressional investigations in partisan environment
May influence public perception of both Clinton and Trump regarding Epstein associations ahead of 2024 elections
Raises questions about proper procedures and ethics in congressional hearings following photo leak incident
Could prompt broader examination of all political figures' connections to Epstein network
May impact future willingness of former officials to cooperate voluntarily with congressional investigations
